title: Policy for the Responsible Use of AI in Government

policyAims.title: Embrace the Opportunity
policyAims.description: Enable government to accelerate AI adoption and embrace the AI opportunity
outcomes: Help agencies confidently approach AI governance
Fully realise benefits like efficiency, accuracy and service delivery

policyAims.title: Strengthen Public Trust
policyAims.description: Position Australian Government as an exemplar in safe and responsible AI use
outcomes: Consistent requirements for transparency and accountability
Risk-based oversight of AI use cases
Build community confidence in government AI

policyAims.title: Adapt to Change
policyAims.description: Embed a forward-leaning, adaptive approach that evolves with technology
outcomes: Support agencies at different stages of AI adoption
Requirements that scale with agency's use of AI

pillars.title: Strategy and Oversight
pillars.description: Enable a forward-leaning approach to agency AI adoption with clear accountability and transparency
principles: Adopt AI to enhance efficiency, decision-making, policy outcomes and service delivery
Have clear accountabilities for AI adoption and understand its use
Build public trust through transparency about government AI use

requirements.title: AI Transparency Statement
requirements.description: Publicly available statement outlining approach to AI adoption and use
details: Must follow Standard for transparency statements
Review and update annually or on significant changes
Notify DTA when published or changed

requirements.title: Strategic Position on AI
requirements.description: Develop a strategic position emphasising how AI opportunities can be identified and embraced
details: Communicate strategic position to give staff clear direction
Can be standalone strategy, augmented strategy, or other materials
Scale approach to current and anticipated AI use

requirements.title: Accountable Officials
requirements.description: Designate accountable official(s) for implementing this policy
details: Follow Standard for accountability
Notify DTA when designated or changed
Maintain register of accountable use case owners

requirements.title: Accountable Use Case Owners
requirements.description: Designate an accountable use case owner for each in-scope AI use case
details: Follow Standard for accountability
Responsibilities set in the standard
Register maintained by accountable officials

requirements.title: Internal AI Use Case Register
requirements.description: Create a register of in-scope AI use cases
details: Enable recording of accountable use case owners
Share register with DTA every 6 months
Minimum fields listed in Standard for accountability

pillars.title: Preparedness and Operations
pillars.description: Standardise key elements of AI governance to build capability and use AI responsibly
principles: APS officers can explain, justify and take ownership of advice and decisions using AI
AI capability built for the long term
Flexibility and adaptability for technological advances

requirements.title: Operationalise Responsible AI
requirements.description: Establish approach to embed responsible AI practices
details: Process for adopting AI use cases aligned with policy and governance
Inform staff about Australia's AI Ethics Principles
Pathway for staff to report AI safety concerns and incidents
Pathway for public to report AI safety concerns
Clear processes to address AI incidents

requirements.title: Staff Training on AI
requirements.description: Implement mandatory training for all staff on responsible AI use
details: Consider Guidance for staff training on AI
Can use AI fundamentals training module via APSLearn
Additional training for staff with procurement/development responsibilities

requirements.title: AI Technical Standard
requirements.description: Apply the AI technical standard for Australian Government
details: Embeds fairness, transparency and accountability principles
Technical requirements and guidelines for AI systems

requirements.title: AI Procurement Guidance
requirements.description: Refer to Guidance on AI procurement in government
details: Step-by-step advice for identifying AI-specific risks
Maintain procurement best practices

pillars.title: AI Use Case Impact Assessment
pillars.description: Assess potential impacts of AI use cases and ensure oversight of higher risk AI
principles: Ongoing monitoring and evaluation of AI uses
AI risk mitigation is proportionate and targeted
AI use is lawful, ethical, responsible, transparent and explainable

requirements.title: Assess All New AI Use Cases
requirements.description: Assess all new AI use cases against in-scope criteria
details: Document assessment during design phase
Apply criteria from Appendix C
Existing use cases assessed by 30 April 2027

requirements.title: In-Scope Use Case Impact Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct AI use case impact assessment for in-scope cases
details: Use Australian Government AI impact assessment tool
Or internal process integrating all provisions
Add to internal register and update as required
Regularly monitor and evaluate deployed use cases
Re-validate assessment on material changes

requirements.title: Medium-Risk Use Cases
requirements.description: Consider additional governance for medium-risk use cases
details: Governance through designated board or senior executive
Appropriate for size and scope of agency

requirements.title: High-Risk Use Cases
requirements.description: Additional requirements for high-risk use cases
details: Report to agency accountable official with risk details
Govern through designated board or senior executive
Report to DTA through accountable official
Regular review every 12 months minimum

inScopeCriteria.description: Use, misuse or failure could lead to more than insignificant harm
AI materially influences administrative decisions affecting stakeholders
Public directly interacts with or is significantly impacted by AI without human review
AI uses personal/sensitive data or security classified information
Deemed elevated risk as directed by DTA

riskAreas: Automated decision making of discretionary decisions
Administration of justice and democratic processes
Law enforcement, profiling individuals, border control

ai.definition: A machine-based system that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers from the input it receives how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments. Different AI systems vary in their levels of autonomy and adaptiveness after deployment.

aiUseCase.definition: A specific application of an AI system or systems to achieve certain objectives or perform certain tasks.

aiIncident.definition: An event, circumstance or series of events where the development, use or malfunction of one or more AI systems leads to: injury/harm to persons, disruption of critical infrastructure, violations of human rights or applicable laws, or harm to property/communities/environment.
